Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Simple Trapeziectomy and Trapeziectomy with Ligament Reconstruction and Tendon Interposition for Trapeziometacarpal Joint Osteoarthritis

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised to simple trapeziectomy (n=25) or trapeziectomy with ligament reconstruction and tendon interposition (LRTI) (n=29)

Participants.evidence: 54 participants with painful trapeziometacarpal joint osteoarthritis

Intervention.evidence: randomised to simple trapeziectomy (n=25) or trapeziectomy with ligament reconstruction and tendon interposition (LRTI) (n=29)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess radiographic progression of degenerative joint disease, changes in pseudarthrosis height, and the association of degenerative changes with clinical outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: clinical outcomes were measured using the Patient Evaluation Measure (PEM), Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) questionnaires, and thumb key pinch strength at 1-year and 6-year follow-ups.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 54 participants with painful trapeziometacarpal joint osteoarthritis, randomised to simple trapeziectomy (n=25) or trapeziectomy with ligament reconstruction and tendon interposition (LRTI) (n=29).

Result_Outcome.evidence: At final follow-up, 7/25 simple trapeziectomy cases and 1/29 LRTI cases exhibited increased degenerative changes.
